newsitem.title: USA: U.S. corporate bond spreads tighten in thin trade.
newsitem.headline: U.S. corporate bond spreads tighten in thin trade.

text.p: U.S. corporate bond spreads enjoyed one to two basis points of tightening on Thursday after indications of a brisk manufacturing sector sent government securities sharply lower, dealers said.

The Treasury yield backup sparked buying across all high-grade corporate bond sectors with cable and tobacco names faring best, said one trader at a big New York shop. Talk of better buying was couched in light volume, however, with hosts of sell- and buy-siders extending holidays through week's end.
Volume came from the bigger accounts but was still estimated at around 25 percent of a normal day.

"There's particular buying from insurance companies, at least in the 10-year sector," one trader said. "Not a groundswell, though -- yield bogeys are being hit and that's really the driving force," he said, referring to targeted levels which trigger buying for many traders.

Upticks in the National Association of Purchasing Management (NAPM) overall and price indeces sent Treasuries down more than one point at mid-morning, analysts said. The NAPM index rose to 54.0 in December against 52.7 in November while the price index rose to 51.5 from 45.9.
The benchmark 30-year T-bond closed off its lows but down 1-6/32 at 96-30/32 to yield 6.74 percent. Some government bond traders pegged 6.85 percent as the next stop for the T-bond.

Back in corporates, Tele-Communications Inc debt was solidly bid and spreads tightened by two basis points on average, a trader said. TCI 6-7/8 percent senior notes of 2006 traded in a 87 basis point bid, 82 basis point offer market.
One market participant said a front-page Wall Street Journal article of Thursday sparked some interest in the company's bonds.

Turning to high-yielders, the ailing Treasury market was blamed for price erosion there and most paper was quoted off 1/2 to one point. Some retailers, including CompUSA Inc, took the brunt of losses after disappointing holiday sales reports.
CompUSA's 9-1/2s of 2000 were seen off one point to a 102-1/4 bid, 102-3/8 offer, one trader said.
Dealers stressed perceptions of strong fundamentals and cash-laden investors underpinned the broad market, which allowed improvements on a spread basis.

High-yield desks were better staffed on Thursday although the head-count failed to translate into activity. Like in high-grades, however, high-yield activity would likely be minimal until early next week.
"No one is willing to make a trade," one high-yield trader said. "I think a lot of junior guys are holding down desks and they could get a little nervous making a trade down here."
There were no straight corporate debt issues priced on Thursday. Several medium-sized high-yield issues were in the works for January, syndicates said.
